narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Comprehensive overview of economic inequality's evolution in the Us-very interesting material

We learned about some simple, and some very complicated, ways to measure inequality. We distinguished between different trends (ie income vs. consumption) that have characterized the US over the past 70 or so years. The class also definitely taught us to read analytical economic and econometric papers, which can sometimes we quite dense.
Learned about the various forms of inequality
I learned a lot about various measures of inequality and what they mean.
A better understanding of inequality and social mobility issues. Also some basics of using the STATA package.
I learned a lot about different economic inequalities.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths- covers a lot of material pertaining to inequality, both historical observations, as well as methods to study and analyze inequality. 

Weaknesses- Pretty poor class participation. Many students did not attend lecture live and kept their cameras off.

Strengths: Dr. Attanasio is kind and a crazy smart and well-accomplished economist. The lectures were fairly well organized and the slides were well made.


Weaknesses: This class was not the best in many way ways. For starters, the assignments were SUPER unorganized. We didn't get our first assignment until like week 7 of class. What's more, we didn't even know what kinds of assignments we would get for the first 6 weeks. The final projects we ended up getting were actually empirically hard. I luckily had some coding experience but if someone had never coded before, I have no idea how they would have completed that project. This is especially unfair considering there were basically no prereqs (or a coding requirement). Second, the lectures were very boring. They were all pure lectures at 9am with basically no classroom participation. It was very hard to focus. I would have appreciated some alternate formats (like breakout rooms) to break the rhythm of the class). Lastly, Dr. Attanasio is very approachable, but also not great at structuring and answering questions in a way that's helpful. Even his instructions were very confusing. I , and most everyone else I spoke to in class, was confused by some of the asks for the final project.

This course was a good combination between theoretical economics and the practical results and implications. However, although we really explored labor inequality, we did not spend so much time on social mobility.

Professor Attanasio covered the topics in detail. 
It could be improved by spreading the problem sets throughout the semester.

I think the material was good, but there was definitely too much reading material. Not even all of the required ones ended up being discussed in class. I think it would be better to narrow down the readings to the essential ones.

I also think some assignments could have been pushed forward so that students do not procrastinate until the end of the semester. Feedback would have also been nice.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes if you are more interested in the material than a traditional classroom experience
Take this course if you are interested in studying how to measure inequality, what variables are used to measure inequality, and if you want exposure to some more advanced economic papers.

I would not recommend this course to other students in its current format. Dr. Attanasio is a kind and crazy smart/well-accomplished economist, but this class was not the best for many reasons. For starters, it was not very engaging at all. The lectures were fairly well organized and the slides were well made and detailed, but most of the class was dedicated to him just lecturing to a bunch of empty screens. He never really tried to engage the class or tried alternate formats to increase participation and break up his lecturing (ex: breakout rooms). The fact that it was at 9am made engagement even lower. In his defense, he tried to get feedback and was always open to hearing students out which is a great quality, however, the class really lacked in the engagement category. The assignments were also SUPER unorganized. We didn't get our first assignment until like week 7 of class. What's more, we didn't even know what kinds of assignments we would get for the first 6 weeks. The final projects we ended up getting were actually quite empirically challenging. I luckily had some coding experience but if someone had never coded before, I have no idea how they would have completed that project. This is especially unfair considering there were basically no prereqs (or a coding requirement). The assignments themselves were also kind of challenging and time consuming. We only had to complete 3 of the 4 but I felt like I spent at least 12-15 hours and wrote like 7 single spaced pages for each. Thus, this course felt SEVERELY backloaded as far as workload. I did nothing for the first half of the course (like literally nothing) and had SO MUCH to do in the later half. Tying to that, we got literally 0 feedback the whole semester. We have no grades at all -- and it's literally a toss up to see where our grades are at when they come out. Lastly, Dr. Attanasio is very approachable, but also not great at structuring and answering questions in a way that's helpful. Even his instructions were very confusing. I , and most everyone else I spoke to in class, was confused by some of the asks for the final project.

All to say, this class definitely has potential. Dr. Attanasio is a sweet professor who will undoubtedly make this course better in the future. However, based on this semester, I would not take this course again. I got very little out of it.

I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in inequality and the various ways to quantify it and interpret the results. It is really cool to see the various factors that come into play throughout growing or shrinking inequality.
Yes. This course is suited for everyone interested in learning about the important economic issues beyond the conversational level.
Yes, because economic inequality is not as simple as one would expect.
